revised_title: The Near Invention of Partition Chromatography by the Robinsons in 1934
tldr: In 1934, Robert and Gertrude Maud Robinson almost invented partition chromatography while researching plant-petal pigments at the John Innes Horticultural Institution. They used a long bandage soaked in a solvent containing anthocyanin and anthocyanidin, hoping that cellulose would show a preferential affinity for the glycosidal residues of the anthocyanin. Although their experiment did not result in the invention of partition chromatography, it laid the groundwork for future research in the field.
